review: Quite simply, the most entertaining popular science book that I have ever read! I read it in college, and I go back to it again and again...

Couldn't we imagine interplanetary travel some 20 to 30 years from now? Then, at last, man will be able to break the invisible fetters that have chained him to this planet from times immemorial and strike out into the infinite reaches of the Universe!Let me give you another instructive instance to graphically illustrate this sham cooperation between ants.Suppose elephants were born in eggs. Wouldn't the egg-shell be very thick? I wager that even a cannon ball wouldn't pierce it and that a new firing weapon would have to be invented.Should you ever chance to fall into a shaft drilled through the earth's centre you would bob endlessly pendulum-like from end to end. It would take you 84 minutes to get from end to end.An invisible man sees nothing.

This is a fantastic book that explains some of the more common yet easily misunderstood aspects of physics using everyday examples and experiments that the reader can carry out themselves. It uses simple easy to follow language without coming across as condescending to the reader. This is definitely Physics for Entertainment and I can't wait to have a go at Perelman's other works.

It covers the physics in Mark Twain's barometer soup, birds on power lines, perpetual motion machines, ice breaker ships, cuttle fish's rocket propulsion, the Invisible Man's sight, and many, many more. Some equations are sprinkled in so you make your own calculations, e.g., how many turns of rope you need to hold a ship in dock. Tons of fun! 99 review questions at the end.
I purchased this from Powells in Portland. It's been highly entertaining and informative so far. I usually need Wikipedia and a calculator on hand whenever I open it.
An amazing book. It made me interested in Physics when I was in high school. Too sad the author of this amazing series has died from hunger in world war 2!
A lot of it zoomed over my head, but this had some really fun things about physics, I even find myself going over what I learned from the book in my daily life at times now.

This was one of my very early reads when I was in the 5th or 6th class. The book had a Malayalam translation which was available thanks to the collaboration between Russian & Kerala publishing houses (Prabhath book house I guess).This book helped me to get a curiosity towards science and especially physics from a very young age. Amazing malayalam translation by Mr. P.K Gopalakrishnan. I guess I was one of the lucky few to have got hands on this book (2 volumes) at such a young age.I still keep these copies (hard-bound) at home. Rescued them from my parents place -and they have a coveted spot in my home library.

Recently remembered this book when I saw an experiment at a local science fair which jogged my memories. I used to spend hours and days pouring over this book, as a kid, even though I had a hard time understanding parts of it. I think it played a huge role in getting me interested and excited about science. The "flashback" made me google for its name, find its author and the English version. I think reading it again ( now that I'm an engineering grad student ) would be a great experience since now I would probably understand all of it.

I highly recommend this book for children. I read it very very long ago but it still has its marks in my mind. It's a scientific one -as the name implies- that presents classical physics in a very interesting way and matches it with everyday's phenomenon and opens up children's minds to more wondering. Things like why glasses are broken when you pour hot tea in it, when it won't break if it had a spoon inside? In which direction should you jump when getting off a running bus, and which direction to throw your bags? Very very interesting.http://arabic.rt.com/books/book/93/

I have this book, from my grand father. Yakov Perelman Volume 1 and 2 Foreign Language Publishing House. this old books are really nice.You can learn physic in a different way. and its really memorable books because my husband proposing me by sending notes inside this book id gave him before..lovely.

The best way to get introduced to physics!!This book continued to entertain me even as I became interested in the so called hi-fi concepts in physics. It does more than just entertain - it really makes you wonder at least till you know what really happens behind the scenes.Indeed, a genuine reason to feel bad about the fall of Soviet union!
An excellent book for school students.
Book 1 doesn't seem to be around. This one is obviously an old book with old references by a foreign guy. Interesting thought experiments though, well at least most of them anyway.
My absolute favorite book on science when I was growing up. I'd read it once every six months!
i think this book very nice tow love physical
This book is translated from 1930's Russian so I think that makes the book more difficult to read than it would be were it written today in English. Interesting little nuggets of physics though.
Can be downloaded free in public domain from Make Magazine. Bruce says it's pretty cool and could be worth getting a hard copy of.
Glad to have read this as a child!
it was a good book for the science students

The one that got me into physics.
Best physics book that I ever read.
